An eye for make believe.
 
 Some people have declared that our eyes, if the part of a designer, are poorly designed. I don't see this. What I do see is an eye that allows us to enjoy beauty, art etc. Sure, we don't have X-ray vision, but our eyes are good enough. (I mention X-ray vision; what basis do people lay claim that our eyes aren't good enough; that we can't see through walls?)
 
 If we can now focus on possible evolutionary path-ways for the eye, we will see that evolutionaries have an eye for make believe.
 
 The classic case (http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/evolution/library/01/1/l_011_01.html) Darwin looked at several existing eye structures, and suggested that this progression of simplest to more complex types of eyes might be suggestive of a path taken in human eye evolution.
 
 Firstly, the core word is 'might'. Thus it is not the all conclusive proof Darwinists would suggest. Where is the evidence that random changes did occur as they say? What caused these changes? Why were they only positive changes? As Michael Behe points out there's enormous complexity in re-arranging the DNA just to get a depression...Behe, M, "Darwin's Black Box", p16ff. Where is the molecular explanation?
 The Darwinist say..."Every change had to confer a survival advantage, no matter how slight." Why? What about dead-ends? What about negative mutations?
 
 What Darwin has shown is what we can call 'conceptual evolution'.The logic behind this is akin to showing a series of pictures: skateboard, bicycle, motor-bike, motor car, etc. We can see that they get more complex, but did the design for a car stem from that of a skateboard? We see the connection between these things (eyes, vehicles etc) because we organise it in our brains... but I'm not going to explain perceptual organisation. 
 
 There are other explanations (http://www.biol.lu.se/funkmorf/vision/evolution.html) The Lund Vision Group shows computer modelling to suggest how a complex human eye could evolve (see under Computer Modelling)
 "the structures of a focused camera type eye can evolve in less than half a million generations" (Ibid.)
 Wow that's quick... so in all that time we're to assume that they went around with mutations that still hadn't quite produced a working eye. It's a shot in the dark, but it might work, providing that the intervening generations didn't need proper vision! 
 
 In just six diagrams we get a model of the eye. This is again a case of conceptual evolution... seeing patterns that are meaningless unless you draw a connexion between them. Richard Dawkins is so impressed with this that he features the image on his web-page.
 
 The fraud is more clearly seen at http://www.don-lindsay-archive.org/creation/eye_stages.html
 
 If you look at the few diagrams here, starting with a light sensitive patch, moving to a more complex eye, we can see the deception of using a rubbery model. The thin line at the top of the light-sensitive spot does not change in each model, yet in the end is the lens! The light-sensitive spot wouldn't have a lens... so the one little line which remains the same in each picture represents in fact vastly different things.

Richard Dawkins claims that the eye is, by fact that it is poorly designed, proof against a creator.
 
 This is an interesting logical flaw. By stating a subjective view of an eye as a conclusive proof he has left hismelf open to attack.
 
 How is the eye 'flawed'? He claims because it is 'poorly wired'. But the eye does function, and does so quite admirably.
 
 Further, by stating that he can see a 'poor design' likewise we can now look for 'good design' to discern a designer!
 
 
 That is to say, if he can show that some things have evolved, simply by how they are put together, we can now look at how all thigns are put together in order to see if there is proof of a good order, and therefore a good design, therefore a designer.
 
 Thanks Dawkins!

The Darwinist say..."Every change had to confer a survival advantage, no matter how slight." Why? What about dead-ends? What about negative mutations?

 
 
Wow that's quick... so in all that time we're to assume that they went around with mutations that still hadn't quite produced a working eye. It's a shot in the dark, but it might work, providing that the intervening generations didn't need proper vision! 

 
 dawkins address many many other issues, and by far does not present the assertion that the eye is not very well designed as his strongest argument.
 
 Dwakins also explains about mutations (negative and positive), as well as why 100% of an eye is not necessary for survival (most humans do it every day). 
 
 You make it sounds like these are some how unresolved issues with evolution... I've already seen you represent someone out of context, and radical changes of subjects... is this misinformation?

This is as silly as saying that designers of the car evolved their idea from a skateboard.

he uses end points as examples because that is what we have available to us now.  If you guys read the article linked from monty's first post, you'd see a sketchy, but plausible senario for the development of the eye: 
 
Here's how some scientists think some eyes may have evolved: The simple light-sensitive spot on the skin of some ancestral creature gave it some tiny survival advantage, perhaps allowing it to evade a predator. Random changes then created a depression in the light-sensitive patch, a deepening pit that made "vision" a little sharper. At the same time, the pit's opening gradually narrowed, so light entered through a small aperture, like a pinhole camera.

 still, a light sensitive depression in the skin is still a long way from a rolling eyeball with independent suspension and eyelids, as well as skull formation around it...
 
 this sketch still raises a lot more important questions: why is the eye in the head? why are eyes in pairs? why do eyes work conjunctively and cooperatively? why are the eyes placed symetrically?
 
 if a light-sensitive spot suddenly appeared on an animal's skin, it could have been anywhere on the body. and it could be any number of light-sensitve patches of any shape or size.
 
 the argument of lack of intelligent design seems limited to the fact that the blood vessels run above the retina and not beneath it. yet nobody is able to conceptualize a working eye using any other design. the fact that vision is so accurate with the existing design might mean that alternative designs to "improve" eye structure may end up bring worse results.

 If you guys read the article linked from monty's first post, you'd see a sketchy, but plausible senario for the development of the eye: 

 
 Here's how some scientists think some eyes may have evolved: The simple light-sensitive spot on the skin of some ancestral creature gave it some tiny survival advantage, perhaps allowing it to evade a predator. Random changes then created a depression in the light-sensitive patch, a deepening pit that made "vision" a little sharper. At the same time, the pit's opening gradually narrowed, so light entered through a small aperture, like a pinhole camera.
 
 
still, a light sensitive depression in the skin is still a long way from a rolling eyeball with independent suspension and eyelids, as well as skull formation around it...

 
 What intermediate step do you think there is no evidence for? Most of the intermediates can still be found in living organisms.
 
 
this sketch still raises a lot more important questions: why is the eye in the head?

 
 Natural selection. It's much better to see where you are going than where you've been. However, non-motile animals don't always have eyes in the head, because there's no selective pressure for it.
 
 
why are eyes in pairs?

 
 They often aren't. Ours happen to be paired because our phylum has bilateral symmetry.
 
 
why do eyes work conjunctively and cooperatively?

 
 Sometimes they don't. In organisms with binocular vision, natural selection applies because it won't work very well if they don't.
 
 
why are the eyes placed symetrically?

 
 They aren't always. But in our phylum, bilateral symmetry means eyes will also be symmetric. (usually) Of course, the first members of our phylum had three eyes. A few still do. We retain it in vestigial form as the pineal gland.
 
 
the argument of lack of intelligent design seems limited to the fact that the blood vessels run above the retina and not beneath it. yet nobody is able to conceptualize a working eye using any other design.

 
 We don't have to. Octopi and squid have the retina "right side out". As a result, they have no "blind spot" as we do.
 
 
the fact that vision is so accurate with the existing design might mean that alternative designs to "improve" eye structure may end up bring worse results.

 
 Nope. It just means that the existing "design" has a slight flaw, and is a bit less sensitive in low light than it would otherwise be.

What intermediate step do you think there is no evidence for? Most of the intermediates can still be found in living organisms.

 
 This is a very interesting use of the word 'intermediate' in a similar fashion 'transitional.' Both of which suggest part of a movement from one point to another.
 
 But these 'intermediate' forms are not intermediate - they are end points... unless you are suggesting that these eye forms are still moving to a more complex form.
 
 You are using what might be termed 'conceptional evolution' - seeing patterns that don't exist.
 
 Let's look at an example
 Think of the following; a skateboard, a push-bike, a motor bike, a car, a aeroplane.
 
 We can see a 'progress' between these from a simple to a more complex form of transport. Thus a motor-cycle could, conceptually be an 'intermediate' form but no one would suggest that a car was only thought up through the steady trial and error of an inventor who had started with a skate-board.

This is a very interesting use of the word 'intermediate' in a similar fashion 'transitional.' Both of which suggest part of a movement from one point to another.

 Of course they are. And they give lie to the assertion that eyes could not have evolved. The very stages that creationists deny could exist are found in still-living organisms.
 
 
they are end points...

unless you are suggesting that these eye forms are still moving to a more complex form.

 No, you're wrong about that, too.  One set of cones in humans has two slightly different forms, with slightly different response to frequencies. If this became more pronounced, humans would evolve a fourth primary color.
 
 Barbarian on th evolution of eyes:
 On the other hand, we can see that it has happened in vertebrates, mollusks and annelids, among others. 
 
 You are using what is termed "denial". The very things that creationists declared could not exist, and hand to exist if evolution was true, are found in living organisms. Pulling back the goal posts this late in the game isn't going to help.
 
 
Nope. One did not evolve from another.

 
 Keep in mind what a transitional is. Living transitionals clearly are not the ancestors of other living organisms. They merely retain a more primitive form that is transitional to more evolved forms. How do we know they evolved? Because, remember, we have the other evidence to verify it. Genetics, anatomy, molecules, etc.
 
 
Let's use a series that did. You need to find transitionals, with evidence of evolution from one to the next.

 
 Sure thing. Let's go with mollusks:
 Here's the diagram of the eye of the limpet (a relatively unevolved mollusk):
 http://www.bradford.ac.uk/acad/lifesci/optometry/resources/modules/stage1/pvp1/images/Patella.GIF
 
 Notice that this one is almost where the python is with infrared receptors. Simple light-sensitive cells in a depression. It can detect light, and to some degree, detect the location of the source.
 
 The next one is this, from the primitive cephalopod, Natuilus:
 http://www.bradford.ac.uk/acad/lifesci/optometry/resources/modules/stage1/pvp1/images/Nautilus.GIF
 
 Notice that it's pretty much like the limpet "eye", except that the depression has deepened, and the tissue has grown over the depression to make a primitive "iris" and "pupil". Much more useful, and capable of forming a crude image by diffraction, much as a pinhole camera works. A lens is nice, but unnecessary.
 
 The next is from a snail:
 
 http://www.bradford.ac.uk/acad/lifesci/optometry/resources/modules/stage1/pvp1/images/Helix.GIF
 
 Not much different, except the cuticle has grown over the opening to provide a transparent protection for the pinhole, preventing it from being damaged or clogged.
 
 And here's a squid:
 http://www.bradford.ac.uk/acad/lifesci/optometry/resources/modules/stage1/pvp1/images/Squid.GIF
 Not much different, except the cuticle and epithelium have thickened over the pinhole to form lenses.
 
 By very small incremental changes, we see that a complex eye can form.
 
 (suggests evolution can be modeled by a motley assemblage of wheeled vehicles)
 
 Sorry. You need to show some independent evidence from several sources, showing that it's right. Try to find a better example.

 Not good enough. Although it is sometimes possible to show a phylogeny by the evolution of pigments. Not a very reliable way to go, though.

as with my skateboard to aeroplane analogy, one didn't lead to the other.

 
 Bad analogy. We don't see any continuity with your example, as we see with the mollusk eyes. 
 
 
They are end points.

 
 If they were, they'd all be the same. But that's not the case. We can see that all of them are transitional to something else.

My understanding is that 'transitional' as used by evolutionaries at present means showing bits of more than one type. Like a bird-lizard creature that is hard to describe to some because it has features of both bird and of lizard.
 
 A light sensitive spot does only show a light sensitive spot. It doesn't show characteristics of more than one type of 'eye'.
 
 Also, on the issue of 'end points' you claim
 "If they were, they'd all be the same. But that's not the case. We can see that all of them are transitional to something else."
 
 How do you know that they are evolving into something else?
 
 
 You can only see that they are intermediates if you group them together in a particular way and look at them and fill in the blanks.
 
 The light sensitive spot of one critter is not becoming a complex eye because that critter, even in evolutionary terms, has what it needs to get by.

My understanding is that 'transitional' as used by evolutionaries at present means showing bits of more than one type. Like a bird-lizard creature that is hard to describe to some because it has features of both bird and of lizard.

 
 "Transistional" means that the organism has characteristics intermediate between two others. 
 
 
A light sensitive spot does only show a light sensitive spot. It doesn't show characteristics of more than one type of 'eye'.

 
 It is intermediate between an organism which has only generalized photosensitivity (such as you have in your skin) and an organism in which the spot is recessed to form a primitive direction detector. Such a set of organisms exists in several phyla. Would you like to learn about some of them?
 
 
Also, on the issue of 'end points' you claim
 "If they were, they'd all be the same. But that's not the case. We can see that all of them are transitional to something else."
 
 How do you know that they are evolving into something else?

 
 They don't have to be evolving to something else. They merely document that a less-evolved eye preceded the more evolved one. They show a stage in the evolution of the particular eye in question.
 
 
You can only see that they are intermediates if you group them together in a particular way and look at them and fill in the blanks.

 
 Right. Just as we can only tell that a particular human has a place in a geneology, by grouping people in a particular way and filling in the blanks.
 
 
The light sensitive spot of one critter is not becoming a complex eye because that critter, even in evolutionary terms, has what it needs to get by.

 
 Yep. Which gives lie to the creationist argument that "half an eye is useless." That was always a bogus argument. But invariably it happens that selective pressure in some environment makes a better eye useful for survival. And then it happens.

 Oddly enough, I went to Sydney University because I wanted to do Scots-Gaelic (my signature is Hail Mary, full of grace .... in Scots-Gaelic), as my background is Scottish.
 
 They have Celtic Studies where you can do the language. However, you had to do a year of Irish first. I did this, and at the end they discontinued the Scots-Gaelic course. I felt like saying 'frig leat' to the lot of them.
 
 Every now and then a temp comes to work with us from Ireland and I brush up a bit - excepting that most of them want to forget Irish as soon as possible - I don't know why there's a stigma to it, but that is the impression I get from those that I meet.
 
 I can still recall pithy sentences such as Ta me i mo chonai ina Baile Wentworth (that's nearest aprox. I can think for Wentworthville).
 
 agus
 
 Nil posta me
 
 agus araile
 
 O, cad as tu?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 ar aon nós
 
 Slan leat go feoil, mo chara, agus Naith Nollaig.

(Barbarian is puzzled why an orthodox Christian would not accept evolution)
 
 
Orthodox Christian teaching - Church Tradition has held that God created.
 
 It's in the Creed. (the Nicence Creed for others)

 
 So why is it hard to accept that God uses nature for his creation? St. Augustine, after all, acknowledged this fact. Nothing in the Creed in any way contradicts a creation by natural processes.
 
 Indeed, God tells us in Genesis..
 
 Gen. 1:24 And God said, Let the earth bring forth the living creature after his kind, cattle, and creeping thing, and beast of the earth after his kind: and it was so.
 
 
We believe in One God, the Maker of Heaven and Earth, of all things seen and unseen...

 
 It's true. But you are a creature of God, are you not? Did He not create you by natural means? And while He also had an intimate part in your creation aside from nature, isn't that true of all things? He created nature, and it works as he wills so that even a sparrow cannot fall without His notice.
 
 Think about it. I'm not being aggressive here; I just want to understand.

PS are you saying that the issues here raised by creationists are not 'serious'?

 
 I figured that was coming. I don’t doubt that your opinions are serious and sincere to you. However you have admitted, as I do, that you have a limited knowledge of science in this area. So I was referring to discussions between biologist or geologists that may even agree with evolution or an old earth but had questions about some details that haven’t been decided on yet. 
 
 But thanks for the link.

I figured that was coming. I don?t doubt that your opinions are serious and sincere to you. However you have admitted, as I do, that you have a limited knowledge of science in this area. So I was referring to discussions between biologist or geologists that may even agree with evolution or an old earth but had questions about some details that haven?t been decided on yet. 
 
 But thanks for the link.

 
 No problemo (see I understand American). That link deals only with creation/evolution stuff. I moved to here from there because this one has much more many interesting debates.
 
 You'll see all your old friends there; WJA (as WJ), Lurch, Iamthetruth etc.

It's true. But you are a creature of God, are you not? Did He not create you by natural means? And while He also had an intimate part in your creation aside from nature, isn't that true of all things? He created nature, and it works as he wills so that even a sparrow cannot fall without His notice.

 
 Commentators/commentaries such as
 St. John Chrysotomon (Homilies on Genesis)
 St Ephraim the Syrian (Interpretaion of the Books of the Bible)
 St Basil the great (Hexaemeron; meaning Six Days)
 St Ambrose of Milan (also wrote a Hexaemeron)
 St Gregory of Nyssa (On the making of man)
 St John Damascene (On the Orthodox Faith)
 St Symeon the New Theologian (The Sin of Adam)
 as well as various other writings by st Gregory the Theologian, St Macarius the Great (of Egypt) , St Abba Dorotheus, St Isaac the Syrian
 to name a few, treated Geneisis as a literal creation.

And many others accepted that it wasn't literal. But my question remains.
 
 If you are a creature of God, and came about by natural means, isn't that sufficient evidence to conclude that God does indeed create by natural means?

And many others accepted that it wasn't literal. But my question remains.

 
 The big-guns of Orthodoxy say it's literal.
 
 
If you are a creature of God, and came about by natural means, isn't that sufficient evidence to conclude that God does indeed create by natural means?

 
 Short answer: No - I didn't come about by natural processes (not entirely, anyway).
 
 Do you believe that you are wholly material? I don't. I believe I have a soul... so unless you have a system that suggests how your soul came into being 'through natural processes' then neither do you!
 
 How does evolution explain your soul? Or, are you one who doesn't believe in a soul?
 
 If you believe the soul is real, and a real part of you, then explain, using naturalistic models how the soul came about - did it come about through a number of intermediate stages?
 
 When did ape-man get a soul?

www.creationtalk.com
 
 
 PS are you saying that the issues here raised by creationists are not 'serious'?

 
 
 Yes.
 
 Jyeager brought up some good points now and then, but that is about it.
 Joe Schmoe is basically worthless, as are the sundry other anti-science chaps.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  An eye for make believe.
